user_request: A poem where the speaker compares a lover to a summer day but concludes the beloved outlasts it.
final_poem:
In whispers of dawn and hues in bloom,  
A love arose where summer'thy days are spun,   
With laughter light as dappled sunbeam glowed;    
Yet winter waits with her frost-kiss cold.     
Your warmth endures through every shadow cast by the moonlight and winds that moan under starry skies unfurling above us high,  
As days of summer's reign to nightfall do succumb;    
So too this fervent season finds its curtain call in evening’st hush.   
But love - like springtime after wintertide weeps and sighs anew with hopes for cherry blossoms,  
And I find that your soul outlasting summer's daydance is a truth more enduring than the sun above as night gives way to morn;      
For even when stars begin their retreat beneath morning’s golden swath and days once again are born anew with warmth in every heartbeat,    
It will be your love that my memory holds dear well beyond this summer's fleeting glow.
